BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Further increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Further increase in danger of dry avalanches as the snowfall becomes more intense.
The new snow is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in many places. The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects and generally above the tree line. Many medium-sized and large natural avalanches are possible.
The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 50 to 70 cm of snow will fall until the evening above approximately 1500 m. The new snow will be deposited on soft layers in all aspects above approximately 1800 m.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable; its surface consists of loosely bonded snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of new snow and wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Gradual increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of new snow and wind.
The new snow is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in many places. The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects and generally above the tree line. Many medium-sized and large natural avalanches are possible.
The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 40 to 70 cm of snow will fall until midday above approximately 1500 m. The new snow is lying on soft layers in all aspects above approximately 1800 m.
Towards its base, the snowpack is favourably layered; its surface consists of loosely bonded snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind.
The new snow is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in many places. The new snow can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant in all aspects and generally above the tree line. Many medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible.
The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow will fall until the afternoon above approximately 1500 m. The new snow is lying on soft layers in all aspects above approximately 1800 m.
Towards its base, the snowpack is favourably layered; its surface consists of loosely bonded snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and in particular the wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and wind dry avalanches are possible from the second half of the night.
The southeasterly wind will transport the new snow. The wind will be strong at times in some localities. The wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack at intermediate and high altitudes. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes, and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. They can be released easily in some places.
Medium-sized to large avalanches are possible. In the typical avalanche paths in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation dry avalanches can in isolated cases reach as far as the valley bottom. In the late morning in some localities danger level 4 (high) will be reached in these regions.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Wednesday: 40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the afternoon above approximately 1500 m. The new snow is bonding only slowly with the old snowpack in particular on very steep east, south and west facing slopes.

The old snowpack is favourably layered.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Wind and new snow. Over a wide area 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1900 m. As a consequence of the precipitation the prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase from the late morning. As the snowfall level rises medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large moist and wet avalanches are possible. In gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at high altitude deep wind slabs will form. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Up to 1900 m rain will fall in some regions. The sleet will give rise to gradual moistening of the snowpack in particular at intermediate altitudes. The fresh wind slabs will become increasingly prone to triggering in all aspects above the tree line. The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall on Thursday in some regions. 5 to 10 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1000 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase in the afternoon. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, above the tree line: The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects and generally above the tree line.
Many small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible.
The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow will fall until the afternoon above approximately 1500 m. The new snow will be deposited on a crust in particular on east to south to west facing aspects.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable; its surface consists of loosely bonded snow. The new snow remains for the foreseeable future prone to triggering in all aspects and generally above the tree line.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the large wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain easily released wind slabs will form. Skiers can release avalanches very easily, including large ones. Remotely triggered and natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowfall will give rise as the day progresses to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in particular on steep slopes. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Over a wide area warming. The rain will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are forming during the snowfall must be evaluated with care and prudence at intermediate and high altitudes. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. In all aspects medium-sized and large avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and wind. Avalanches can be released, even by a single winter sport participant. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow and wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in many places. Individual weak layers exist in the old snowpack in particular on shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be cloudy over a wide area. Light precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from southeasterly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form in the course of the day.
The wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack at intermediate and high altitudes. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more widespread and the danger is slightly greater. They can be released easily in some places. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Wednesday: 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the afternoon above approximately 1500 m. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers.
In the western part of the northern flank of the Alps, along the border with France in some regions 10 cm of snow fell on Saturday. The wind was strong.
The weather was cold.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. The avalanche danger will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The large quantity of fresh snow and in particular the wind slabs formed during the snowfall can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above the tree line, in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In addition medium-sized loose snow avalanches are possible. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some localities over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. The wind will be strong to storm force at times.
Fresh wind slabs will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects above the tree line.
The old snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall on Thursday in some localities. New snow and wind slabs require caution. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. The avalanche danger will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The large quantity of fresh snow and in particular the wind slabs formed during the snowfall can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above the tree line, in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In addition medium-sized loose snow avalanches are possible. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some localities over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. The wind will be strong to storm force at times.
Fresh wind slabs will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects above the tree line.
The old snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall on Thursday in some localities. New snow and wind slabs require caution. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Significant increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
During the day: Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow can be released easily, or, in isolated cases naturally in all aspects above the tree line. These will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Caution is to be exercised in particular on very steep shady slopes, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In isolated cases avalanches are large.

A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Avalanches can reach medium size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 25 to 40 cm of snow, and up to 50 cm in some localities, will fall above approximately 1200 m. The wind will be strong to storm force at times.
Fresh wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
The old snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Some snow will fall in some localities. Gliding snow requires caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Significant increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
During the day: Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow can be released easily, or, in isolated cases naturally in all aspects above the tree line. These will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Caution is to be exercised in particular on very steep shady slopes, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In isolated cases avalanches are large.

A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Avalanches can reach medium size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 25 to 40 cm of snow, and up to 50 cm in some localities, will fall above approximately 1200 m. The wind will be strong to storm force at times.
Fresh wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
The old snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Some snow will fall in some localities. Gliding snow requires caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on west to north to east facing aspects above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase as the day progresses. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 1200 m. The wind will be strong to storm force at times.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on west to north to east facing aspects at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on west to north to east facing aspects above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase as the day progresses. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 1200 m. The wind will be strong to storm force at times.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on west to north to east facing aspects at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on west to north to east facing aspects above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase as the day progresses. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 1200 m. The wind will be strong to storm force at times.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on west to north to east facing aspects at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on west to north to east facing aspects above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase as the day progresses. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 1200 m. The wind will be strong to storm force at times.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on west to north to east facing aspects at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of the precipitation medium-sized wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 2500 m. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow slides and avalanches are possible in isolated cases. These are small.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Only isolated mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible above approximately 1900 m. In gullies and bowls a sometimes precarious avalanche situation will be encountered in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1900 m no snow is lying. The older wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes. As a consequence of the precipitation, the likelihood of wet snow slides and avalanches being released will increase a little.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 1700 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are very rare and are easy to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally wet all the way through.
